name: Linear combinators
intro: A lambda expression (and, subsequently, a combinator) is called linear
if it uses all of its arguments exactly once and adds no new terms.
It can thus compose and swap terms, but not duplicate or discard them.
For example, B and C are linear, but W and K are not.
Combinators built from linear combinators are linear as long as
they don't apply arguments to anything but arguments.
Let's move some terms around!

content.name: Cardinal once removed
intro: Make a combinator that swaps its 3rd and 4th arguments, starting from 1:
C* a b c d = a b d c.
Only linear combinators are allowed.

content.name: The Q<sub>n</sub> Quintuples
intro: Exactly six combinators of form λ a b c . x (y z) (where xyz = abc in some order)
exist. Obviously they are linear.
One of them, B, is already known to us. Here come the other five.
Find the Queer bird: Q a b c = b(a c).

content.name: The Q<sub>n</sub> Quintuples: Q<sub>1</sub>
content.intro: Find the Quixotic bird: Q1 a b c = a(c b).

content.name: The Q<sub>n</sub> Quintuples: Q<sub>2</sub>
content.intro: Find the Quizzical bird: Q2 a b c = b(c a).

content.name: The Q<sub>n</sub> Quintuples: Q<sub>3</sub>
content.intro: Find the Quirky bird: Q3 a b c = c(a b).

content.name: The Q<sub>n</sub> Quintuples: Q<sub>4</sub>
content.intro: Find the Quacky bird: Q4 a b c = c(b a).

content.name: Wait four it
intro: Build a combinator that takes its first argument to the fourth position:
R4 a b c d = b c d a.
(See also the Robin quest).

content.name: Identity but later
intro: Provide a combinator that takes 3 arguments and returns them applied in the same order:
I**a b c = a b c.
The catch is: a and b shall not be merged until c arrives.

content.name: The linear base
intro: This is one of the hardest [citation needed] problems from To Mock a Mockingbird.
It can be proven that I, B, and either C or T
form a basis for all linear combinators.
(Show that C and T are interchangeable here.)
However, does a base of less than 3 combinators exist?
Well apparently it's impossible to get rid of I, but the other two can indeed be merged.
Your task will be to declare a combinator that would, together with I,
form a basis for all linear combinators.
You'll then have to prove it's a basis by implementing B and T.

input.name: P
input.note: Declare your own combinator, lambdas allowed. It should be linear.
